Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story:
My phone buzzes with two notifications at once. The first is from QA: “Production outage—urgent! Users can’t log in. Looks like it’s your module.” My stomach drops. I know how critical this is; every minute down means angry customers and a stern meeting with my manager. I open my laptop, heart pounding, already scanning through error logs in my mind.

Then I see the second message. It’s from Jamie, my closest friend. “I can’t believe you’d say that. I thought you cared.” My last text must have come off cold, and now Jamie’s hurt. I know I should call right now, explain, and fix this before it festers. That’s what friends do—communicate, clear the air.

But the outage is a five-alarm fire. My team and our users are counting on me to fix this, fast. My hands hover over my phone and keyboard, torn. I can’t do both at once. My chest tightens as I weigh the expectations—be a good friend, be a responsible developer. I can’t shake the feeling that, whatever I choose, I’ll be letting someone down.
